item.title: The Most Productive Teams at Google Have These 5 Dynamics
item.description:
The Most Productive Teams at Google Have These 5 Dynamics

Google's People Operations department confronted a paradox. Like most HR organizations, it hired individuals. It developed individuals. It evaluated the performance of individuals. Yet almost everything Google does, it does in teams. The group started thinking, "How could HR be different if we reoriented at least some of our services toward the level of the team?"

item.title: This 'virtual employee' is proof that the robot takeover is upon us
item.description:
This 'virtual employee' is proof that the robot takeover is upon us

IPsoft screen grab When you first meet Amelia, you got the impression that she's all business: white Oxford shirt undernearth a blazer, blonde hair seemingly pulled back in a ponytail. "She," in this case, is an avatar created by IPsoft, the global information technology services company.

item.title: Increase Your Return on Failure
item.description:
Increase Your Return on Failure

Executive Summary Although many companies claim to embrace failure as an integral part of the innovation process, near-zero tolerance for it blocks them from pursuing new ideas. Corporate budgeting, resource allocation, and risk control are all designed to promote predictability and efficiency, and even when people understand that they can and should fail, they do everything possible to avoid missteps.

item.title: The Secret History of Agile Innovation
item.description:
The Secret History of Agile Innovation

You hear a lot about "agile innovation" these days. Teams using agile methods get things done faster than teams using traditional processes. They keep customers happier. They enjoy their work more. Agile has indisputably transformed software development, and many experts believe it is now poised to expand far beyond IT.

item.title: How scientists can make copies of memories,
item.description:
How scientists can make copies of memories,

Undoubtedly the most interesting conversation I had at SXSW was with Dr Ted Berger, who is working on a brain implant to make life better for people who have problems with long-term memory - and the science behind it is fascinating.

item.title: Strategy, not Technology, Drives Digital Transformation
item.description:
Strategy, not Technology, Drives Digital Transformation

About the Authors: Gerald C. Kane is the MIT Sloan Management Review guest editor for the Digital Transformation Strategy Initiative. Doug Palmer is a principal in the Digital Business and Strategy practice of Deloitte Digital. Anh Nguyen Phillips is a senior manager within Deloitte Services LP, where she leads strategic thought leadership initiatives.

item.title: 9 Motivational Videos to Help You Succeed in Business and Life
item.description:
9 Motivational Videos to Help You Succeed in Business and Life

There are videos that energize us, inspire us, and motivate us to do great things. Then there are the very few that do all that--and also touch us so deeply that we wind up watching them over and over again.

item.title: The Laws of Simplicity
item.description:
The Laws of Simplicity

On the one hand, you want a product or service to be easy to use; on the other hand you want it to do everything that a person might want it to do. The process of reaching an ideal state of simplicity can be truly complex, so allow me to simplify it for you.

item.title: The Truth About 'Performance Improvement Plans'
item.description:
The Truth About 'Performance Improvement Plans'

What's the story with Performance Improvement Plans? Here's the scoop.

item.title: Hacking The Career: What Organizations Should Do
item.description:
Hacking The Career: What Organizations Should Do

One of the most disruptive changes we've seen in business over the last decade is the end of the traditional "career." People used to join companies for life: We would look for a great company when we got out of school, join the new-hire development program, pay our dues working up [...]
